ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learning about the power and structure of presidents.
This course taught me how to read the work of many different perspectives and ultimately use those perspectives to form my own.
Deeper understanding of the presidential institution and how it has evolved

I think this course was a great in-depth look at the presidency. It challenged me to think in new and different ways about the office and reexamine what I had already learned about the presidency. I enjoyed the prompts on the midterm essays and I thought I was pushed to be a better writer throughout the course. Though the final exam was a bit daunting, having done it, I have confidence in my ability to learn a whole semester's worth of material and do well on such an exam.

I have become incredibly insightful on the American presidency and as a result I feel more confident in understanding political discourse and the evolution of our government. I think I have the skills from this class to help facilitate better and more knowledgeable discourse on the American government.
different perspective of looking at the presidency, analyzing presidents critically and concentrating on their relationship to the rest of government
I learned the history and development of the Executive in American Government
I learned so much about the American presidency throughout the semester. I have a much greater understanding about what is consisted of our American government.
I gained a lot of insights into the american presidency. We learned about theories around the presidency and spent the first half of the class discussing the history.

-broad knowledge of American Presidents and the institution of the American Presidency
-how the presidency has evolved over time
-how the presidency today is similar and different to the presidency throughout history
Ability to utilize extensive reading for exams and papers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The content is interesting, sometimes hard to follow.

This class is taught as a lecture, however, the professor has no presentation or even guided lecture notes that students can use to follow the information. He stands at the front of the class and talks which makes the class incredibly difficult to follow along.

The course material was very interesting and readings helped to facilitate that. It could be improved by having more concrete slides/notes to supplement Prof. Skowronek's entirely oral lectures. The readings also could be decreased since they are very long and not all of them were discussed in class.

I thought the course was well structured. I found the readings interesting and informative. The lectures were also well done and interesting. I think that sometimes the essay prompts asked more questions than I thought could be effectively explored in the length of the midterm papers.

This class is primarily strengths. I enjoyed the structure and I believe Professor Skowronek was incredibly talented and helpful in this class. My only recommendation would be to provide more time to read certain texts and to have slightly more structured lectures.

strengths: good discussion sections, interesting perspectives

weakness: a lot of reading in a week that cannot even be covered in the weekly discussions
Better lecture, some sort of reference like slides
It was difficult to stay engaged with lectures throughout the semester; as no visuals during the lectures made it a challenge to stay in tuned.

I liked this class a lot the readings were good and the lecture material was really interesting. the weakness is that there are no slides, so sometimes lectures were hard to follow and I had to take notes on everything which made studying more about culling through what was actually needed and what was just repeated material.
The Professors lectures were horrible. No outlines, notes, PowerPoints. Nothing. Everything was just reading off a paper

-material is interesting
-material is applicable to current day
-lectures aren't very engaging
-reading was incredibly dense and too long
Great lectures however not a great utilization of canvas and tech resources to obtain class information and updates.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, there is interesting content.
For students who might need any sort of visual aid in a lecture style class, I would not recommend it.
Very interesting course material, not the best experience in terms of managing your workload and notes

Yes - Professor Skowronek's framework of looking at the Presidency is important to acknowledge as we continue to choose our leaders for the future. In an age of "Presidentialism," Yale students should be excited that they have access to a course that asks the questions we will grapple with far into the future.
Yes, if students are interested in political science and the presidency, this is a great and informative course.

I would highly recommend this class because I truly think I have a better understanding of our government and the importance of the presidency in modern times. I think I truly learned the importance of evolution in the presidency and its current impact on us.
if you are interested in just the presidency and how it affects government
Yes! Skowronek is so knowledgeable!! You will learn a lot from him!
I would recommend this course to any political science major; as well as anyone who desires to learn more about the American government and presidency.
Yes, if you can follow a lecture with no slides its really interesting
No
If you are interested in the presidency as an institution, this class is for you. However, be prepared to sit through some dry lectures.
